Author: Rennard Marquez#2403
Content:
i got this bug after checking through cs50.

üò¶ is_tie returns false when only some of the candidates are tied
    is_tie did not return false

can someone explain this or give an example? i can't quite comprehend it. üò¶ thanks!

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it means that your program didn't return `false` when it should have.  `is_tie` should return true if every candidate remaining in the election has the same number of votes, and should return false otherwise.  So let's say you have 4 candidates remaining and 2 have 6 votes and 2 have 4 votes.  Your `is_tie` function should return false in that situation, but your program is returning true.  @Rennard Marquez

curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @clarxino the candidate you want to check for elimination is the one in the preferences[i][j]. (ie, the one that was voted for).  If that candidate hasn't been eliminated, you want to increment its votes.  Remember that preferences[i][j] holds the id of the candidate, so perhaps you can store that value in a variable inside the loop, and then use that to index into your candidates array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Notice that the tabulate function is not passed any arguments, so you can't access any variable unless it is globally declared.  Your function should be calculating the votes for all candidates, so there is no `name` to compare. You only need check if the candidate has been eliminated or not.  And the candidate you are checking each time is based on the preferences array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you want to return true if *all* the non-eliminated candidates have the same number of votes. (ie, if all of them have the minimum).  Your code only returns true if the final candidate has the minimum and is throwing away any information about the other candidates.

Author: ra9#3988

Author: ra9#3988

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if all the non-eliminated candidates have the minimum, then it's tied.  That leads to the inverse that if any of them doesn't have the minimum it's immediately false.

Content: it seems like you've got some mix up with your code there

Content: im guessing you're confused with how preferences{i][j] work

Author: Mendax#3549
Content: you should take a look at how the vote function works in main and what input it passes it into your function

Author: Mendax#3549
Content: lets take this case as example just so we're on the same page

Author: Mendax#3549
Content:
Candidates List:
1. Adam
2. Belle
3. Charlie

1st Voter Max:
1st preference: Belle
2nd preference: Charlie
3rd preference: Adam

Author: Mendax#3549
Content:
if i were to run the program uses your code however, it would work like this:

1. Main asks Max for his first preference.
2. Max is the first voter, therefore i = 0, and j = 0 as his first preference. Main passess i = 0 (voter), j = 0 (rank) and string name Belle to the vote function
3. the vote function recieves "i" which is voter, "j" which is rank and Belle
4. your vote function then compares candidate[0].name, which is Adam, to Belle

Author: Mendax#3549
Content: and essentially you see how your vote program only compares 1 candidate to the string name

Author: Mendax#3549
Content:
what your vote function should be doing is:
1. Compare string name to all available candidate names (maybe use a loop?)
2. If the string name matches any of the candidate names
3. Index said candidates candidate number into preferences[voter][rank]

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: remember that you are updating the votes total for the voter's top preferred candidate that hasn't yet been eliminated.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so for each voter  you loop through their preferences until you find the one that isn't eliminated and that's the one you update.  The voter's preferences are stored in preferences[voter] (which is what your outer loop is looping over) and the ranks for that particular voter are in preferences[voter][rank] (which your inner loop is looping over).  So if you have voter 0  and there are 5 candidates, then you'd check candidates[preferences[0][0]] to see if it's eliminated, if it isn't, then you update its votes and you're done with voter 0.  If it is, then your inner loop runs again, and now you are checking candidates[preferences[0][1]]  and you keep repeating until you have gone through all voters.

Author: LampEight#4604
Content: Hi all, hitting my head against a brick wall with a compiler error in my tabulate function that I am not comprehending properly. In my head, the values I'm calling are both of type int. Clang says no... what am I missing here?

Author: Anya L#2162
Content: @LampEight candidates[j] is a struct, not int. You're accessing different parts of it even here: e.g. candidates[j].votes is in fact an int if I recall correctly. j is also an int, which you can compare if apropriate. If you're getting confused about what variable holds what value, it's really helpful to rename i and j more descriptively

Author: LampEight#4604
Content: @Anya L thanks for the clarification but still not sure where to go from here. What I'm struggling with is the process for: "If the j'th candidate matches voter i's' current 'j'th preference, then increase this candidates vote, else cycle to next candidate". I can't seem to formulate an expression to check this against? I managed this in plurality with just strcomp but how do I match the two up with indexing alone?

Author: Anya L#2162
Content:
@LampEight I find using i and j misleading when there're so many different values to keep track of here. How about: 
```index_of_candidate = preferences[voter][preference]```
and
```candidates[index_of_candidate].eliminated
candidates[index_of_candidate].votes```
Thus, if voter [0] has top preference (also [0]) for candidate with index 2, you check if number 2 is eliminated, and if not - add votes. If candidate 2 is eliminated, look up voter [0]'s preference [1] and check if this one is eliminated. Stop once you've assigned a vote for this voter and move on to voter [1].

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so there's a loop for each voter `i`and within that, another loop to get each of their votes in order `j`.    The voter and candidate index, along with the candidate's name, are then passed to the vote function.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: So if you have 2 candidates, say, Joe & Jane, and 2 voters who each vote for Joe first and then Jane, the vote function will be called for voter 0 and get their first preference (then calling `vote(0,0,"Joe")`, then for voter 0 and get their 2nd preference (calling `vote(0,1,"Jane")` ... then i increments to 1 for the next voter and asks for first vote (and then calls `vote(1,0,"Joe")`) and then second vote `(vote(1,1,"Jane")`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so your vote function is called each time the user types the candidate name.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `i` and `j` therefore are voter and rank

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
Let's say you used the example in the spec:  ```./runoff Alice Bob Charlie
Number of voters: 5
Rank 1: Alice
Rank 2: Bob
Rank 3: Charlie

Rank 1: Alice
Rank 2: Charlie
Rank 3: Bob

Rank 1: Bob
Rank 2: Charlie
Rank 3: Alice

Rank 1: Bob
Rank 2: Alice
Rank 3: Charlie

Rank 1: Charlie
Rank 2: Alice
Rank 3: Bob```

Author: lawfulevilgenius#6705
Content: ok so preferences[0][0] would be alice

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: it would be alice's index in the candidate's array

Author: lawfulevilgenius#6705
Content: preferences[0][1] would be bob

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `./runoff Alice Bob Charlie`  the first thing that happens is the candidates array is populated in order

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so candidates[0] is for Alice, candidates[1] is for Bob and candidates[2] is for Charlie

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so anytime someone votes for Charlie, that would mean that the preferences array for that voter/rank would be set to 2

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or if they vote for Alice, it would be set to 0

Content: You can run `echo $?` at the command prompt to find out the return code of the last program that just ran.

Usage: runoff [candidate ...]
~/pset3/runoff/ $ echo $?
1
```

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: You can funny things with that, like `./prog1 && ./prog2`. The second programme will run only if the first returned with an exit code of zero (so it's about the opposite of C, 0 would indicate success). Likewise, `./prog1 || ./prog2` will run the second one only if the first one did not succeed, and returned an exit code other than zero.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: in C, we return 0 to indicate success. üôÇ

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Yes, but `false` is `0` (and almost everywhere non-zero is considered true). I mean - `0` would short-circuit a `&&` in C code, while it short-circuits a `||` in exit codes.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: That's a bit confusing at least, if you are used to this kind of thinking.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I get what you mean.  `0` in the return code means "there were no errors" so in that respect it means false  if the question is "were there errors?"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: much like `strcmp` returns 0 when the strings have no differences.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but many people think of strcmp as "are these strings the same?" and then are confused when `0` means they are.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `strcmp` gives the relative order, not just whether the strings are equal or not.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: yes, I know that.  But how many times have you seen someone (*wrongly*)  do `if (strcmp(a,b)) == true` or `if (strcmp(a,b))`  assuming that it returns true/false üôÇ

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: my point is that you have to ask the right question

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I usually don't combine the unfiltered result of `strcmp` with logical operators.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that's because you understand the function üôÇ

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: j+1 won't increment j for the next time around the loop

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: let's say it was a simple array like `int num[] = {1,2,3,4}`

Author: lawfulevilgenius#6705
Content: ok

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and that `j` is our increment in the for loop, looping over the array

Author: lawfulevilgenius#6705

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so let's say that `j` is now 1.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so num[j] has a value of 2.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: num[j] = num[j+1]  will mean that num[1] will now be 3.  And the array will be {1,3,3,4}

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and now let's say whatever out while condition is is true, so the do while repeats.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and we set num[j] = num[j+1] again.   but `j` is still 1

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so all we do is set num[1] to num[2] and our array is still {1,3,3,4}

Content:
`find_min` should definitely not change any votes. I would not consider this "working fine".
You already did `plurality`, I assume? In `plurality`, you have to find the maximum number of votes. Here, you need to find the minimum number among the non-eliminated. While for the maximum, 0 was a reasonable starting value, I think here `voter_count` would be reasonable (as that's the maximum number of votes a candidate might have).

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Looks good, but you only want to increase the vote for the highest non-eliminated candidate on the voter's list.  What that means is you want your inner loop to stop once you find the candidate and increment the vote.  But you want the outer loop to keep running, so you can move to the next voter.  The way to do that is put a `break;` statement after line 163.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Carly ^^

Author: Carly#9697
Content: @curiouskiwi Thank you the test passed now! I am confused on how break works in this situation I'll have to look more into it

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `break;` ends any loop that it is in.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: (but only the inner loop if it's in a nested one)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: or more formally: "When a break statement is encountered inside a loop, the loop is immediately terminated and the program control resumes at the next statement following the loop. "

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you're running into integer division problems.  the votes and voter count are both integers, so you'll end up with 0 * 100 which is 0.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @Carly try casting one of those to a float  to force floating point division

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `!` means not

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so `!vote` reverses the value that your `vote` function returns.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if your `vote` function returns true, then `!vote(i, j, name);` will be false.  So the if condition will be false, and you won't print "invalid vote"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if your vote function returns false, then the if condition is true, so main prints "invalid vote" and returns 4.

Author: Aimer#8978
Content: what does number 4 indicate?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: 4 is simply an error code.  Generally, if main returns a value other than 0, it indicates an error.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: this program uses different values if you were running the program as part of a larger one, you could check what it returned to know the conditions under which it failed.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and when you call a function, the variable names in `main` don't have to match the variable names of the function's arguments.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: which is why you don't see `rank` or `voter` in the call to `vote()`

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: Is someone able to help with my tabulate function? Not sure how to make it so if there's a tie between 2 people in rank 1 votes, how to make the function look at whether these 2 people come up as rank 2 in the orderings, which would help settle the tiebreak.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @YoYoO For each voter, find the candidate with the lowest rank/highest preference that hasn't been eliminated yet. Increment that candidate's `votes`.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: There shouldn't be any loop variable used as index to `candidates`, as we want to visit them in order of voter preference.

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content:
Can someone confirm for me what the result would be if there are 2 voters, with 3 candidates to choose from (Bob, Tom, John) who vote as follows:

1. Bob
2. Tom
3. John

1. John
2. Bob
3. Tom

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: It would be declared a tie, correct? Even though in the second ranking Bob is **second** and in the first ranking John came **third**.... right? Bob *wouldn't* be declared the winner, right?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: First round, John and Bob have one vote, Tom gets eliminated. Second round, again John and Bob have one vote each, this time that's the `min` votes, so it's a tie.

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: Yep cool, I confused myself thinking Bob would win.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Such weird things could happen in `tideman` only.

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content:
Hey there, I have actually found a "bug", or better yet something that the checker in runoff does **not** check for. My code got 100% in terms of functionality according to the grader, but actually returns the wrong answer under the condition in the picture.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you don't need to loop through them all until you find the candidate.  Simply update the vote for the candidate that you have been given.   `preferences[i][j]` holds the candidate id.  Loop through the entire preferences array and give a vote to the first non-eliminated candidate for each voter.  Let's say you have 3 voters and 4 candidates.  So `i` will go from 0 to 2 and `j` from 0 to 3.  The first time through the loop you are getting preferences[0][0]  (the candidate that is top preferred by voter 0)  Lets say we store preferences[i][[j] into a variable called `voted_for` each time.  So if candidates[voted_for] is not eliminated, you increment the vote and then break out of the loop (so that you don't check any more candidates for voter 0).  Now you've moved to `i` = 1.   `voted_for` becomes preferences[1][0]  ... let's say that he's eliminated.  `j` = 1 now.  `voted_for` becomes preferences[1][1] ... and he's not eliminated, so we increment his vote.  break the loop so you stop looking at voter 1 and then `i` is now 2. you loop over preferences[2][0]  etc etc.    You're done once you've looped over all the voters.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
When talking about the highest number of votes in `plurality`, the natural choice for the maximum would be to start at 0, as no candidate could have less.
In `find_min`, the highest number of votes a candidate could get is all of them. So if you initialise the minimum to `voter_count`, you're on the safe side, you can always update it downwards. Of course, any higher number would do as well.

Author: thehorserapper#6794
Content: you don't need to loop through them all until you find the candidate.  Simply update the vote for the candidate that you have been given.   preferences[i][j] holds the candidate id.  Loop through the entire preferences array and give a vote to the first non-eliminated candidate for each voter.  Let's say you have 3 voters and 4 candidates.  So i will go from 0 to 2 and j from 0 to 3.  The first time through the loop you are getting preferences[0][0]  (the candidate that is top preferred by voter 0)  Lets say we store preferences[i][[j] into a variable called voted_for each time.  So if candidates[voted_for] is not eliminated, you increment the vote and then break out of the loop (so that you don't check any more candidates for voter 0).  Now you've moved to i = 1.   voted_for becomes preferences[1][0]  ... let's say that he's eliminated.  j = 1 now.  voted_for becomes preferences[1][1] ... and he's not eliminated, so we increment his vote.  break the loop so you stop looking at voter 1 and then i is now 2. you loop over preferences[2][0]  etc etc.    You're done once you've looped over all the voters

curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I don't know what part of the problem you are working on

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and you have an array of them in `candidates`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so if you run `./runoff Joe Jane Jimmy`  then candidates[0] will be for Joe, candidates[1] will be for Jane and candidates[2] will be for Jimmy

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so that means `candidates[2].name` will be "Jimmy"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and `candidates[2].votes` will start off as 0

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and `candidates[2].eliminated` will start off as false

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: now, the preferences array holds the preferences for each voter, so if there are 5 voters, then `preferences[0]` will hold the ranked votes for that voter.  So if voter 0 gave these ranks in order:  Jane, Jimmy, Joe ... that would mean that `preferences[0][0]` (ie, the highest rank) would be for Jane.  Jane is `candidates[1]`, so `preferences[0][0]` is set to 1.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `preferences[0][1]` would be 2  (since Jimmy is `candidates[2]`) and `preferences[0][2]` would be 0 (since Joe is `candidates[0]`)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: that continues for all 5 voters

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
`print_winner` looks like you didn't understand the difference between `plurality` and `runoff`. Here, we need a simple majority, not a relative majority. And since it always returns `false`, the game never ends.
Most of the other functions are wrong, too, often struggling with the elimination of candidates. What if the first candidate is no longer available? What if the first `n` candidates have been eliminated? Your code should deal with that.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: To "relative" vs. "simple": Only a simple majority would ensure that further elimination steps won't change the winner.

Content:
Hello CS50, I've been stuck on PSET3 runoff for the last week. I've watched Brian's hint video 5 times, and the lecture twice, and still can't seem to figure it out.

I have completed 5 of the 6 functions, and they seem to work when i put in debugging print statements etc...but when I try to run it normal nothing seems to work. I can't seem to find where the problem is.

So I would like to post my functions one at a time and get some feedback. Maybe my issue is in my earlier functions and I just don't realize it.

Here is my vote function: My thought process was to update the preferences[voter][rank] each time a ballot came in. So I created a loop to go through each [rank] until i got to the candidate_count value, then iterate the [voter] and repeat until I got to the voter_count...

Any help/feedback would be appreciated.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: No need to change `rank` and `voter`, their new values wouldn't affect the calling code anyway, because C uses call-by-value, all the parameters contain the *values* passed to the functions, they have no connection to the variables used in the calling code.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I mean this is useless, but at least it doesn't break the function.

Author: gtacs#3034
Blauelf#6622
Content: The calling code has a loop where it increments the rank, and calls your function again with the next voter/rank combination.

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: huh, well isn't that something. I had no idea...

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: i've been struggling on this for a week

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: tyvm, i going to go back and study the main prog again

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: There's no such thing as this `rank`/`voter` increment in the function description, nor does your function have any way to influence the variables of `main`.

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: I see it now plain as day

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: just a follow up question then: Why does the function say it takes Int voter and Int rank as an input ?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Those are the three parameters, `voter`, `rank`, and `name`. There's no connection to the side of the calling code, in this case they use `i`, `j`, `name`, but it could also be `11+12`, `0x2A`, `"Marvin"`, as values are passed, not variables. Everyone picks names according to their own context.

Author: gtacs#3034
Content: @Blauelf so are the values, from the main prog, "i", "j", and "name" being passed to the vote function as "voter" = the value of "i", "rank" = the value of "j", and "name" the value of "name"?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Correct

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
`while` with a body that ends in `break` or `return` is exactly the same as an `if`. But you do need an inner loop, and you have to increment exactly one candidate's votes.
`i` is not an index to `candidates`. The various `preferences[i][j]` are.

Author: gtacs#3034
Content:
ok, I see, I need an inner loop to handle the situation when a candidate is eliminated? I forgot about that. If the first choice is eliminated the second choice gets counted...
Is it ok to put an array in an array i.e. candidates[preferences[i][j]]++ or do you need to get an integer for the value at preferences[i][j]?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Is perfectly fine to use it there. It's also perfectly fine to assign it to a variable if you use the value multiple times or think it greatly improves readability.

Content: is it normal to break your entire program because you accidentally used > instead of < then spend an hour trying to figure out what went wrong?

Author: Chook#2868

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
Sometimes happens. But you can't tell that to your boss. "Spent like half a day because I incremented the wrong variable" isn't something they want to hear.
At work, we have such great internal APIs that won't tell you if you passed the wrong parameter. The result is just wrong, the parameter with the typo ignored. With bad to non-existent documentation, and too many indirection layers added, each layer in another person's responsibility, that's even harder to locate.
So yes, tiny mistakes can keep you busy for some time, better hope the programme fails close to the problem.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Maybe `Ctrl`+`C` in the terminal to send a `SIGINT` (an "interrupt" signal).

Author: Chook#2868
Content: cheers

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `SIGINT` is usually a nice way of asking a programme to interrupt what it is doing, often this is synonymous to "quit". `SIGTERM` is a bit harder, really asking it to quit. `SIGKILL` is the hardest, as you could guess from the name.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
Here's a scenario that can help testing.  4 candidates Alice, Bob, Charlie, David  with 7 voters, giving these preferences:  ```
7
Alice
Bob
Charlie
David
Alice
Bob
Charlie
David
Bob
David
Alice
Charlie
Bob
David
Alice
Charlie
Bob
David
Alice
Charlie
Charlie
Bob
David
Alice
Alice
Charlie
Bob
David
```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
if you save that in a file like "test.txt", then you can run ```
./runoff Alice Bob Charlie David < test.txt```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
and you can then see if this is the same thing you get (I've added a lot of intermediate printing for each stage)  ```
round: 0
Alice gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Charlie gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
+++Vote totals+++
Alice: 3
Bob: 3
Charlie: 1
David: 0
eliminating David
round: 1
Alice gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Charlie gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
+++Vote totals+++
Alice: 3
Bob: 3
Charlie: 1
David: 0
eliminating Charlie
round: 2
Alice gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
Bob gets a vote
candidate Charlie was eliminated
Bob gets a vote
Alice gets a vote
+++Vote totals+++
Alice: 3
Bob: 4
Charlie: 0
David: 0
Bob```  so Bob is the final winner.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
your vote function is passed 3 arguments.  ```bool vote(int voter, int rank, string name)
{```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so your function finds the candidate with that name, and then updates the preferences array for that voter and rank with the index value for that candidate.

Author: Mayank#3199
Content: is voter and rank my local variables or global variables??

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: they are the values being passed to your function by main

Author: Mayank#3199
Content: sir can you tell me which line in the code does it?? I mean they have declared the function before main

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
so if you run `./runoff A B` with 3 voters.   ```
$ ./runoff Alice Bob
Number of voters: 3
Rank 1: Bob  
...
```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: then `vote` will be called with `vote (0, 0, "Bob")`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: since the first voter's first preference is "Bob"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so your vote function would then find the candidate index value for "Bob" if it exists

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and if it does, you'd update preferences[0][0] with that value (in this case, with 1)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: since candidates[1] is "Bob"

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
then the program prompts for ```
Rank 2: Alice```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and vote is called with `vote(0, 1, "Alice")` since it's still the first voter and their second preference

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and you'd update preferences[0][1] with 0  (since candidates[0] is Alice)

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: your function of course doesn't care that it's [0][1] or [0][0] but uses the argument variable names preferences[voter][rank]

Author: Mayank#3199
Content: sir but if (!vote(i, j, name)) is just checking the condition for validity of name. how does it pass to bool vote(int voter, int rank, string name)??  I am not getting point??

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: since those are the variables that you are given

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you are calling `vote`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `vote(i, j, name)`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the line `if (!vote(i, j, name))`   calls the vote function with those values and then that function returns either true or false after updating the preferences array.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if it returns false, that means the "if" will be true  (because `if !false` is true) and main will print "invalid vote".

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if it returns true, then the voting loop will run again to get the next vote

Author: Mayank#3199

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: just like other functions you are using like `strcmp`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: and `printf`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the difference is that those functions are in libraries that have been included, but `vote` is a function in your program itself.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: if that's confusing, I'd suggest you rewatch the Functions short from week 2.

Author: bec#7264
Content: the way I like to think of it is that preferences[i][j] is a function that returns the index of the candidate that is the jth preference of the ith vote

Author: bec#7264
Content: and since it outputs the index of the candidate you would keep the function where you would input the index of the candidate

Author: bec#7264
Content: what "candidates[preferences[i][j]]" essentially does is it goes to the jth preference of the ith voter gets the candidate index from there and then puts that candidate index in the candidate array to find out the information of the candidate like the name and such

Author: bec#7264
Content: it's very verbose but you gotta break it up and think about em individually to get how it functions as a whole

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: I have hopefully a simple question: are we assuming that it either doesn't matter if someone chooses the same candidate multiple times or that we wouldn't use that as an input? For instance, if someone votes Alice, Alice, Alice with 3 candidates, should me program count the second and third preferences as invalid or just process them and ignore them if she gets eliminated?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you should assume that no one would enter the same candidate twice.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: (in other words, don't do any special handling)

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @ganesh003 For each voter, you should walk through their preferences in a loop (your loops match so far, just that the inner one should be understood in terms of "rank", not "candidate number"). If their preference of the current rank is still in the game, give that a vote, continue with next voter, skipping the other ranks.

Author: ganesh003#9251
Content: why am i getting these two warnings?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
@ganesh003 At some point you treat `j` as a candidate index, at another point you treat it as a number of votes. You are meant to return a number of votes.
For that, you would have to find a better starting value (like the highest number of votes a candidate might have).

Author: illectronic#2285
Content: So, I really don't get how a runoff election is supposed to be like. Is it the majority of the first? If first has none, majority of the second? etc...

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: First person to receive the majority of votes (anything more than half) is declared the winner. Every time there is no winner, the candidate that received the fewest number of votes is removed and the next choice for that particular ballot is considered.

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: Everyone that had greater that the smallest number of votes stays in. If thereIt repeats until there is a candidate that has > 50% of the vote.

Author: CasualGamerCC#0928
Content: If there's a tie for the smallest number of votes (like 2 out of 4 candidates receive 10 votes each and there is a total of 100 voters with the other 2 candidates receiving 40 votes each) then all the candidates tied for last place are removed.

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: @brian Hi, I'm implementing the Vote function. I'm confused whether an incorrect input makes the whole program exit.

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: For instance if I give arguments, as Alice, Bob, and Charlie. My program with the input "a" tries to match thru the candidate[i].name structs, and obviously doesn't get a name "a" and prints invalid vote

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: And then subsequently exits.

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: Is the line "return 4;" at fault here, or am I making a simple thing complex?

Author: brian#1055
Content: The problem lets you assume "that all voters will rank all of the candidates in their preferred order", so the program is only designed to handle the case where all names are correctly provided. No need to worry about incorrect inputs!

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: @brian Thank you for the help!

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: And can I know what return 4 means

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: I've scoured the internet to no avail...

Author: brian#1055
Content: If a program exits successfully, it usually returns with a status code of `0`. If there's some sort of error, programs usually return with a non-zero number. Different numbers (1, 2, 3, 4, etc.) are just used to denote different errors.

Author: Nick_jo#6430
Content: Ahhh. Okay. Got it! Thanks again!

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: The checker uses its own `main`.

Content: That means your modification was not in code run by the checker. And it also means that if you change function signatures, the checker's `main` will likely not compile.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Arpan Maity Does your function always return `true` if any non-eliminated candidates have different than `min` votes?

Author: Arpan Maity#0682
Content:
@Blauelf i dont think it will return true always.
moreover i am not really getting the use of min in the function

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
You would have to compare `count` against the number of remaining candidates times the number of remaining candidates minus one.
Would be easier if you used `min`. A tie means all the remaining candidates have the same number of votes. `min` is the minimum number of votes among the remaining candidates. So in a tie, all the remaining candidates have `min` votes.
Or, by inverting the logic: If you find any non-eliminated candidate with more votes, it's not a tie.

Content: "simple majority", not "relative majority".

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Not half of the votes at minimum, but more than half.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
If you have half of them, it might turn out a tie. Consider
`./runoff A B C`
```
6
A
B
C
A
B
C
A
B
C
B
C
A
B
C
A
C
B
A
```

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
First round, it's 3xA, 2xB, 1xC. C is eliminated.
Second round, it's 3xA, 3xB. No winner.

Author: felix#0141

Author: Singularity#9064
Content: `preferences[i][j]` is the j^th preference for voter i. It contains the index of the candidate who is the j^th preference.

Author: Singularity#9064
Content:
Let's take an example, 

Let's consider Voter Index 4 (the fifth voter). This voter has to rank the candidates. 


The first preference for this voter is `preferences[4][0]`, the second preference is `preferences[4][1]` and so on. 

Now, suppose that the first preference for this voter is Candidate Index 3. 

Then, 

`preferences[4][0] = 3` 

We store the index of the candidates, and not their name. 

This is because we can then directly get a candidate by their index.

Author: Singularity#9064
Content:
For example, if you wanted to get the name of the candidate who is the first preference for the 5th voter, it would be 

`candidates[preferences[4][0]].name` 

And since candidates have other properties like `votes` and `eliminated`, it makes sense to store the index of the candidates and not their names  

If you stored their names, you'd have to run a search in the candidates list to find their index and then access their other properties.

Author: Singularity#9064
Content: @felix

Author: nuni#4630
Content: @rb you are checking if the voter first(and subsequential if necessary) preference is eliminated or not. you have each voter preference stored in a 2D array, where in each [][] it will be stored an integer, which signify the index position of the candidate in the candidates arrays. It is like : ok in position 0x0 there is a 3. so you then use 3 in candidates[] array to  access that candidate true/false elimination status.

Author: nuni#4630
Content: And the 2d array works that each each row stores one voters preferences, so 0x1 will be voter 0 preference 1,0x2 will be voter 0 preference 2, 2x3 will be voter 2 preference 3

Author: nuni#4630
Content: @rb  is it the why we move over the rows in the 2d array that is not clear?

Author: rb#1417
Content: no, it's just i didn't know the syntax.

Author: rb#1417
Content: ||candidates[preferences[i][j]]].votes|| is what I i don't fully get.

Author: rb#1417
Content: I am guessing preferences[i][j] acts as an index?

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: Yes.  Imagine the array drawn out, if it was a max of preferences[x][y] then there would be x rows each with y columns.

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: So it makes a grid.

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: [i][j] represents one square in that grid.

Author: nuni#4630
Content: yes the value of i moves over the rows and the value of j moves inside each row, for every value inside the row. so because we want the candidate preferences starting with their first choice, we start from the assumption (because we made it like this) that each row is filled with the voter preference, so for each candidate we ideally look at their first preference [i][0] but if the candidate index inside [i][0] match a candidate that has been eliminated, then we move the the voter second preference, [i][1] and check what values is the second preference. I think the confusing bit is that inside the preference array there are not names but integers. this refers to candidates array, so depending in which order the user wrote the candidates name in the command line, that will be their index. So if my candidates are entered as ``` ./runoff Alice Bob``` Alice will be referred as 0 and Bob as 1. Like their name will not enter the preference array, only their index in the candidates array

Author: Berufius#8341
Content: I'll give it a try, please correct me if I'm wrong: Preferences is an array that contains the list of preferences for each voter. As you can see at the top of the code, it is an array that contains integers only. So the first voter [i=0] has on the top of his list [j=0] a number of the candidate that is on top. This number corresponds to the i-th candidate of the candidates array.

Author: Berufius#8341
Content: @AK

Author: Berufius#8341
Content:
So if the list of the first voter is candidate nr.4, nr.6 and nr.3, preferences will have the following values:
preferences[0][0] = 3, preferences[0][1] = 5 and preferences[0][2] = 2. Keep in mind that each array starts at 0

Author: Anshul#1883
Content: WHat is the total no. of votes ? Can someone explain mathematically how total no. of votes of a candidate are evaluated after  someone is eliminated

Author: Berufius#8341
Content: @Drew I had exactly the same issue, haha, unforgiving computers

Author: Berufius#8341
Content: @Anshul after a candidate is eliminated all votes of all candidates are set to 0. The next round votes are counted again, but only for candidates still in the race.

Author: Anshul#1883

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when you run the program, you say `./runoff Alice Bob Charlie` for example.  candidate_count gets set to 3.  That code loops 3 times and fills the candidates array for each candidate.  It sets their name, their votes (0) and their elimination status.

Author: coldfusion#5932
Content: yeah that first line is making the ith candidate's name the i + 1th value in argv, remeber that argv[0] is ./runoff so argv[0 + 1] is the first candidate in argv. Then that second line makes all the candidates votes 0 as no votes have been counted, and that third line in the loop basically says none of the candidates are eliminated yet by setting eliminated to false for all candidates

Author: dearestalexander#8379
Content:
üôÇ runoff.c exists
üôÇ runoff compiles
üôÇ vote returns true when given name of candidate
üôÇ vote returns false when given name of invalid candidate
üôÇ vote correctly sets first preference for first voter
üôÇ vote correctly sets third preference for second voter
üôÇ vote correctly sets all preferences for voter
üôÇ tabulate counts votes when all candidates remain in election
üôÇ tabulate counts votes when one candidate is eliminated
**üò¶ tabulate counts votes when multiple candidates are eliminated
        tabulate function did not produce correct vote totals**
üôÇ print_winner prints name when someone has a majority
üôÇ print_winner returns true when someone has a majority
üôÇ print_winner returns false when nobody has a majority
üôÇ print_winner returns false when leader has exactly 50% of vote
üôÇ find_min returns minimum number of votes for candidate
üôÇ find_min returns minimum when all candidates are tied
üôÇ find_min ignores eliminated candidates
üôÇ is_tie returns true when election is tied
üôÇ is_tie returns false when election is not tied
üôÇ is_tie returns false when only some of the candidates are tied
üôÇ is_tie detects tie after some candidates have been eliminated
üôÇ eliminate eliminates candidate in last place
üôÇ eliminate eliminates multiple candidates in tie for last
üôÇ eliminate eliminates candidates after some already eliminated

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: Let's look at your example.  The first voter ranked B as their first choice.  So your vote function would be given voter 0, rank 0, "B".  Your job is to set the preference for voter 0  (ie, preferences[0]) and their first rank 0  (ie preferences[0][0]) to the index from the candidates array for the candidate with the name "B".  So you've looped over the candidates array, looking for "B" and when you find it, you set preferences[0][0] to 1  (because candidates[1].name is "B")

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @cantseejack does that make sense?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: different error codes

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: 0 means no errors and anything else is an error

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: the main function could return 100 if there were thjat many possible errors

Author: Bald cape#0371
Content: so the no after return is the no of possible errors?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: no its just the "error code" that you want to signal

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: for example, returning 3 could mean the user didnt format their input correctly, 6 could mean an error opening a file, etc.

Author: Bald cape#0371
Content: ah so basically 0 means no error and other are just errors too but specifed with diff numbers to identify them?

Author: coldfusion#5932
Content: @Bald cape yes by convention, it exits and returns 0 if there were no errors and if main returns something else it means something went wrong. 1,2,3,4,5, etc. are used to signify any error that occured just to help determine what went wrong

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: @Sneks Your data looks correct. Without looking at your code I will say this about tabulate. I initially over complicated it. Not counting the function signature and starting & ending curly braces my function is like 10 lines counting new lines. A hint would be that sometimes a While loop inside a For loop is helpful if you want to do something a certain number of times but, not while something else is true. Think of how you need to increment J and when you need to increment J, and when you don't

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: @Sneks wow you are incredibly close. Like 98% right. In your code I would hint toward asking, why do you need that break? In fact you really really don't want to break out of the While loop in that scenario. What if I have multiple candidate eliminated and J needs to equal 2? And given that first If condition with eliminated why do you need the second?

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: Think of it this way. J starts at 0, then you increment to 1 while preferences are eliminated, then break. So now J = 1, then if the candidates not eliminated you given them a vote

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: What if you didn't break and didn't have that second If?

Author: Sneks#2007
Content:
well i took the break out, 
which of cause makes sense, so [j] can can increase itself in the while loop  until the statement of .elimate  for [j] becomes false.

as soon as this happens increase the vote for candiate in ballot [i] for postion [j] 
(regardinless if theres is an if condition or not.. (since the if condition is kind of a doulbe check ther))..

However, taking out the if condition dosen't fix my problem

Author: LegendaryLootSocks#0997
Content: Good you took the break out. You are right the 2nd If is redundant. You just iterated while [i][j]eliminated is true, so it makes sense the next [i][j]eliminated is false. So you can delete that If as it's useless.

Content:
:) runoff.c exists
:) runoff compiles
:) vote returns true when given name of candidate
:) vote returns false when given name of invalid candidate
:) vote correctly sets first preference for first voter
:) vote correctly sets third preference for second voter
:) vote correctly sets all preferences for voter
:) tabulate counts votes when all candidates remain in election
:) tabulate counts votes when one candidate is eliminated
:) tabulate counts votes when multiple candidates are eliminated
:) print_winner prints name when someone has a majority
:) print_winner returns true when someone has a majority
:) print_winner returns false when nobody has a majority
:) print_winner returns false when leader has exactly 50% of vote
:) find_min returns minimum number of votes for candidate
:) find_min returns minimum when all candidates are tied
:) find_min ignores eliminated candidates
:) is_tie returns true when election is tied
:) is_tie returns false when election is not tied
:) is_tie returns false when only some of the candidates are tied
:) is_tie detects tie after some candidates have been eliminated
:) eliminate eliminates candidate in last place
:) eliminate eliminates multiple candidates in tie for last
:) eliminate eliminates candidates after some already eliminated

yay! the only reason why my print function wasn't being marked correct in check50 is because I didn't declare winningvote_count as a local variable, I declared it as a global variable. If you put it inside the function, check50 works correctly

Author: thuer#0322
Content: In your pseudo-code, You're iterating over every voter, then every candidate, which is right, you then need to check that candidate against the voter's preference in the first slot. You're ONLY checking if that first candidate is still running before you go ahead and add a vote to them, you're not checking to see if they were that voter's first preference.

Author: thuer#0322
Content: As in, you need to make sure that the candidate that you're checking is the candidate in that voter's first preference spot in preferences[i][j].

Author: sdperez77#2905
Content: A note that may help others running into problems with check50: the check50 algorithm appears to be quite strict so even when my code worked perfectly, check50 said the output was wrong. For example, it said my print winner function was incorrect because my mathematical expression was set up as (potential winning candidate's number of votes / voter_count > 0.5. Why is this different than (potential winning candidate's number of votes > voter_count / 2 ?

Author: ddm135 | Aut#5379
Content: you are dividing 2 ints

Author: ddm135 | Aut#5379
Content: so there won't be any thing after 0

Author: ddm135 | Aut#5379
Content: and 0 is < 0.5

Author: sdperez77#2905
Content: Ah, got it thank you!

Content: @EternalExplorer the staff has requested that we use spoilers to hide our code. Just put the following before and after your code. ||

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: If the code contains the same as "or" then you probably want to take a screenshot and post that with spoiler

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: When posting an image, you just need to check the box for spoiler

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: First off I'm not sure why you're clearing the vote count.

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: Tabulate is a function that runs more than once during the process.

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: So basically you are wiping the vote count multiple times. Which is going to be a problem

Author: OneEmpty#4864
Content: At least I think so. I could be wrong

Author: EternalExplorer#3560
Content: Thank you, @OneEmpty! Apologies for the naked code... I figured it wasn't a spoiler if it didn't work. I've gone ahead and hidden it and will be mindful to hide any future code posts as well. My thinking was clearing the vote count would avoid previous tabulate vote counts adding up... I'll try without it as you suggest
